home.homeHeroSubTitle: The tools of tebori may seem primitive compared to modern tattoo machines, but the principle was the same

heroBottomImageList.description: Tebori is the traditional Japanese method of hand tattooing that dates back to the 17th century in Japan, specifically from the Edo era, between 1600 and 1868.

Literally 'hand-carved' tattoos. Artists used a slender bamboo or metal tool with a needle grouping attached to the tip to manually push ink beneath the top layers of skin, leaving a permanent mark for either decoration or punishment.
Literally 'hand-carved' tattoos. Artists used the rods to manually push ink beneath the top layers of skin, leaving a permanent mark for either decoration or punishment.

homeImageList.title: Oni Mask Tattoos
description: A synonym for an Oni mask would be that of demon whose origin is of a Hindu-Buddhist belief system.
Oni’s are believed to be the reason for setbacks.
An Oni possesses beastly characteristics and moves slowly because of its size.
An Oni is powerful despite its speed and has an in-your-face nature.

homeImageList.title: Okame Tattoos
description: Okame is a religious figure in Japan.
She is considered a Goddess of good fortune, happiness, and mirth. eastly characteristics and moves slowly because of its size.
You will frequently hear the word “mirth” associated with Okame, which means someone has a glad spirit and an easy laugh.

homeImageList.title: Kappa Tattoos
description: Being part of the Yokai family, the Kappa is a creature found in Japanese folklore.
Kappas are bizarre in their features and have a hole in their head filled with water.
The Kappa will reciprocate but also spilling all of their secrets. A Kappa will be internally grateful if someone refills the water, and for that, they gained a companion.

portfolio.alt: A picture with the artist performing the traditional tattooing technique on a man's shoulder
portfolio.title: Shoulder piece
portfolio.content: The artist doing a koi sleeve. this happened at Calgary Tattoo Show!!

portfolio.alt: A black and white picture with a full back tattoo of Kokuzo-Bosatsu on a man's back
portfolio.title: Kokuzo-Bosatsu back piece
portfolio.content: Ryugen, specializes in traditional Japanese imagery --colorful, cartoon-like forms inspired by nature, religious iconography and the country's famous 'ukiyo-e' wood block prints.

portfolio.alt: A colorful full back and thights dragon tattoo on a man
portfolio.title: Dragon back piece
portfolio.content: He is one of a small number of Japanese artists still practicing the ancient tradition of 'tebori' tattoos.

portfolio.alt: A black tattoo on side of wribs of a man
portfolio.title: Side pieces
portfolio.content: Horiyoshi III is a horishi (tattoo artist), specializing in Japanese traditional full-body tattoos, or 'suits', called Irezumi or Horimono.

portfolio.alt: A black full back tattoo on a man with many many details
portfolio.title: Full back piece
portfolio.content: Horiyoshi III is the second tattooist be granted that honorific title, which passes from master to apprentice. The tattooist affixation Hori means to engrave or 'to carve'.

portfolio.alt: A colorful full body tattoo on a man with a dragon, a leopard, a phoenix and other symbols
portfolio.title: Full body piece
portfolio.content: Horiyoshi feels responsible for keeping the classic repertoire alive, 'one prick at a time.'

portfolio.alt: A colorful full back and thights dragon tattoo on a man
portfolio.title: Koi fish sleeve
portfolio.content: His specialties are Oriental body suit and realistic portraits in both color and black & gray.

portfolio.alt: A colorful full back and thights dragon tattoo on a man
portfolio.title: Dragon and koi sleeve
portfolio.content: He is known as a master of New School Oriental art style where you find elements of realism and materialism in his tattoo.

portfolio.alt: A colorful full back and thights dragon tattoo on a man
portfolio.title: Dragon sleeve
portfolio.content: His art brings a new realism to the culture and stories of Asian traditions.

artists.name: Jess Yen, aka Horiyen
artists.description: From humble beginnings in Taiwan, Jess Yen has grown to be an internationally known master of the new school of oriental art. Under his touch, the creatures of Japanese and Chinese mythology flow with life, alive with detail, shadow and light.
artists.quote: When I use the needle and ink to create art on skin, the art becomes a living thing.

artists.name: Horiyoshi 3
artists.description: Muramatsu bestowed this title upon Nakano in 1971. He restricts his motifs to the classical repertoire of the vast variety of traditional Japanese stories and designs: peonies, koi, dragons, tenyo (she-angels), etc.
artists.quote: The creatures I draw only come alive on somebody's skin. This is why I never show my designs as so-called art. I draw simply for fun and to have samples to show my clients so they can pick a new design. The creatures depicted take the person's breath away once they are on his or her skin — and then the two start breathing together, in unison. Human history alters the look of the animals and plants I paint, and when the person wearing them dies, so too do they.
artists.quoteSource: Horiyoshi III, Words to Live By, The Japan Times Online

artists.name: Ryugen
artists.description: Ryugen's instruments, which he keeps in a simple fabric pouch, differ little from these centuries-old tools, although he uses disposable needle tips for the sake of hygiene. Demonstrating his technique, he rests one of the rods along the crease of his thumb before moving it in a repetitive, vigorous action -- a sort of digging motion.
artists.quote: From a young age, I was interested in history. And I particularly like the Edo period, which was when these tattoo design was developed. I'm not religious, but I like the designs of Buddhism, the Edo period and samurai. The way I do it is the same as a machine, the needles are disposable and I wear gloves. But people think that tebori is dirty, or not safe, because it's very primitive.
